translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽The Chapter about the Giver of Fruits
The Elder Ajjunapuppha
On the bank of the Candabhāgā River,
I was a kinnara then;
I saw the dust-free Buddha,
the self-dependent, the unconquered.

analyzed: pasanna cittaḥ sumanaḥ  veda jātaḥ katañjalī
translated: With a confident mind, joyful,🔽with awareness, my hands raised in reverence,
I took an ajjuna flower
and worshipped the self-dependent one.
By that well-done deed,
by my intention and aspiration,🔽I abandoned the kinnara body🔽and went to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.

analyzed: jahitvā kinnaram deha  tau atisamagacchaha  chattisakkhattum devindo  deva rajjam akārayi
translated: Thirty-six times I was Sakka,🔽the king of the gods, I ruled the kingdom of the gods;
Ten times I was a universal monarch,
I ruled the great kingdom.
The extensive local kingdom,
incalculable in number,
The seed sown in a good field,
was for me in the self-dependent one.
I have done what is skillful,
I went forth into homelessness;
I am worthy of worship today,
in the teaching of the Buddha’s son.
My defilements are burned up,
I live without pollutants.
Welcome indeed it was for me,🔽…
The Buddha’s instruction has been fulfilled.
The four discriminations,

original: kataṁ buddhassa sāsanaṁ”.🔽Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā ajjunapupphiyo thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
analyzed: katam buddhassa sāsana  ittham sudam āyasmai ajjunapupphiyaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati
translated: I have done the Teacher’s bidding.”🔽Thus have I heard: this was said by the venerable Ajjunapupphiya.
The Story of Ajjunapupphiya the Elder is finished.
